Idiom (Samoan): Ua ta le fuata ma lona lou
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Every action or decision carries its natural consequence
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Traditional wisdom referring to harvesting and its outcomes
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Samoan): ua ta le ˈfu.a.ta ma ˈlona lou
First Example Sentence: Ua ta le fuata ma lona lou, e tatau ona tatou taliaina iuga.
Second Example Sentence: Ua galo ia te ia, ae toe manatu i le upu, 'ua ta le fuata ma lona lou.'
Third Example Sentence: Ua faamanatu mai e le toeaina, 'ua ta le fuata ma lona lou.'

Idiom (Samoan): E pala le ma‘a, a e le pala upu
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Words and promises endure longer than material things
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Ancient Samoan wisdom emphasizing speech’s endurance
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Samoan): e ˈpa.la le ˈmaʔa a e le ˈpa.la ˈupu
First Example Sentence: E pala le ma‘a, a e le pala upu na fai i le nu‘u.
Second Example Sentence: Ua ia ta‘ua le faaupuga, 'e pala le ma‘a, a e le pala upu.'
Third Example Sentence: E pala le ma‘a, a e le pala upu o le tautoga.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: The conversation or mood has died down
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Reference to the shark, symbolic of liveliness and presence
First Example Sentence: Ua gase le malie i le potu ina ua alu le tofa.
Second Example Sentence: Ua fai si gase le malie i le talanoaga.
Third Example Sentence: Ua gase le malie i le taumafataga.

Idiom (Samoan): E lele le toloa ae ma‘au i le vai
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: People always return to their origins
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: Everyone goes back to their roots
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: The duck (toloa) as a metaphor for return
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Samoan): e ˈle.le le toˈlo.a a.e maˈʔau i le ˈvai
First Example Sentence: E lele le toloa ae ma‘au i le vai o lona nu‘u.
Second Example Sentence: E lele le toloa, ae e le galo le aiga.
Third Example Sentence: E lele le toloa, ae toe foi pea i le vai.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: A sacred relationship or boundary has been violated
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Reference to va tapuia (sacred space) in Samoan culture
First Example Sentence: Ua soli le va tapuia i le va o matai.
Second Example Sentence: Ua manatu le toeaina, 'ua soli le va tapuia.'
Third Example Sentence: Ua faalogoina le tala, 'ua soli le va tapuia o le aiga.'

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Everyone carries their own burdens differently
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Samoan): e le tau maˈma.fa le ˈa.mo a le taˈŋa.ta
First Example Sentence: E le tau mamafa le amo a le tagata, ia tatou onosa‘i.
Second Example Sentence: Ua ia fai mai, 'e le tau mamafa le amo a le tagata.'
Third Example Sentence: E le tau mamafa le amo a le tagata i lona olaga.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Service or loyalty has been rewarded
Usage Contexts: Chiefly titles, cultural events, family discussions
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Reflects Samoan chiefly system, tautua (service) is honored

Third Example Sentence: Ua manatu le nu‘u, 'ua ola le tautua.'

Third Example Sentence: E le mafai ona tautala le isu, e faigofie ona iloa.

Third Example Sentence: Ua le toe fia ai se masima i le oloa tuai.
